docs.abstract: Apple decided several years ago to produce a high-end Mac in Texas. The problems that surfaced illustrate the challenges of domestic manufacturing.
docs.snippet: Apple decided several years ago to produce a high-end Mac in Texas. The problems that surfaced illustrate the challenges of domestic manufacturing.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Despite a trade war between the United States and China and past admonishments from President Trump “to start building their damn computers and things in this country,” Apple is unlikely to bring its manufacturing closer to home.

headline.main: A Tiny Screw Shows Why iPhones Won’t Be ‘Assembled in U.S.A.’
headline.print_headline: Why Not Assemble iPhones in America? Consider This Screw

docs.abstract: Regulators should take a close look at the iPhone App Store.
docs.snippet: Regulators should take a close look at the iPhone App Store.
docs.lead_paragraph: Of the 17 most popular screen-time and parental-control apps in the App Store, 11 have been removed or restricted by Apple. The app makers believe they are being punished for competing with Apple’s own screen-time control tools, or worse, for weaning people off Apple devices. Many of the apps had more stringent controls than Apple’s in-house alternatives. Apple says that the applications — specifically, the parental-control apps — were removed because of their use of Mobile Device Management, a technology that gave third parties access to information such as “user location, app use, email accounts, camera permissions and browsing history.” In other words, Apple says it removed the apps to protect the privacy of the children and parents who installed them.

headline.main: Why Does Apple Control Its Competitors?

docs.abstract: In California, the rise of online retail is supersizing a corporate tax incentive. Banning it would benefit everyone (except corporations).
docs.snippet: In California, the rise of online retail is supersizing a corporate tax incentive. Banning it would benefit everyone (except corporations).
docs.lead_paragraph: When Californians place an online order with Best Buy, they pay the company and they pay a state sales tax. What the receipt doesn’t say is that Best Buy gets some of the sales tax, too.

headline.main: A Very Modern Waste of Tax Dollars
headline.print_headline: A Very Modern Waste of Tax Dollars

docs.abstract: Plus, Apple loses its visionary designer, and Democrats debate how to fix the economy.
docs.snippet: Plus, Apple loses its visionary designer, and Democrats debate how to fix the economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: Here’s all the business and tech news you need to know for this hot, slow holiday week. Happy 4th of July!

headline.main: The Week in Business: Wayfair Employees Want No Part in Migrant Detention Centers

docs.abstract: Worries about the tech industry added to broader concerns, including the impact of the trade war between the U.S. and China.
docs.snippet: Worries about the tech industry added to broader concerns, including the impact of the trade war between the U.S. and China.
docs.lead_paragraph: The stock market’s gains for 2018 were erased on Tuesday, as a sell-off led by giant technology stocks continued. The renewed declines in the United States came after drops in Asia and Europe.

headline.main: Stocks Fall, Wiping Out Gains for 2018

byline.original: By Alexandra Stevenson, Amie Tsang and Matt Phillips

docs.abstract: Our personal tech columnist tracked his sleep for two weeks with an Apple Watch and some software. Here’s why he concluded it was a pointless exercise.
docs.snippet: Our personal tech columnist tracked his sleep for two weeks with an Apple Watch and some software. Here’s why he concluded it was a pointless exercise.
docs.lead_paragraph: For the last two weeks, I’ve added an extra step to my bedtime routine: strapping a computer around my wrist.

headline.main: The Sad Truth About Sleep-Tracking Devices and Apps
headline.print_headline: Data That May Keep You Up at Night

docs.abstract: A series of hearings on Capitol Hill showed the rising force of the political backlash against the country’s tech giants.
docs.snippet: A series of hearings on Capitol Hill showed the rising force of the political backlash against the country’s tech giants.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers leveled stinging criticism and sharp questions at Big Tech executives on Tuesday, attacking Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google for their market power, their perceived bias as gatekeepers of communication and Facebook’s ambitions to reshape the financial industry.

headline.main: Tech Hearings: Congress Unites to Take Aim at Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google
headline.print_headline: Reprimands Of Big Tech Cross Aisle

byline.original: By Steve Lohr, Mike Isaac and Nathaniel Popper

docs.abstract: To rein in monopolies, maybe we need to rethink what a monopoly is.
docs.snippet: To rein in monopolies, maybe we need to rethink what a monopoly is.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a tech galaxy that now seems far, far away, everyone was terrified of Bill Gates. He was the Apex Predator of Tech.

headline.main: Taming the Apex Predators of Tech
headline.print_headline: Taming the Apex Predators of Tech

docs.abstract: Local journalism has been pushed “to the verge of extinction,” said a member of a committee that plans 18 months of hearings and other scrutiny of the big technology platforms.
docs.snippet: Local journalism has been pushed “to the verge of extinction,” said a member of a committee that plans 18 months of hearings and other scrutiny of the big technology platforms.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A congressional investigation into the power of big tech companies began on Tuesday with bipartisan concern from lawmakers that the government’s lax oversight of the industry may be doing more harm than good.

headline.main: House Opens Tech Antitrust Inquiry With Look at Threat to News Media
headline.print_headline: Tech Hearing Scrutinizes Threat to News Media

docs.abstract: The president said his administration would not grant Apple’s request for relief from tariffs on computer parts made in China and suggested he could soon tax French wine.
docs.snippet: The president said his administration would not grant Apple’s request for relief from tariffs on computer parts made in China and suggested he could soon tax French wine.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday that his administration would deny a request by the electronics giant Apple to avoid stiff tariffs the United States had placed on Chinese imports and threatened to hit France with heavy tariffs in response to a new digital tax that will affect American tech companies.

headline.main: Trump Escalates Feud With Apple and Threatens Tariffs on France
headline.print_headline: Trump Squeezes Vise on Apple and Warns France

byline.original: By Jim Tankersley, Jack Nicas and Ana Swanson
